Yes, market makers can manipulate stock prices: Buying and selling large amountsMarket makers can buy or sell large amounts of securities to move the market in a specific direction. For example, they can trigger stop losses or limit buy orders. SpoofingMarket makers can place large orders to buy or sell a security with the intent of canceling it before it's executed. This can create an illusion of high demand or supply, artificially moving prices. Front-runningMarket makers can buy or sell a security knowing that a large order is about to be executed. This gives them an unfair advantage over other market participants. Buying and flippingMarket makers can buy shares for their own accounts and then flip them hours later to make a personal profit. Regulatory bodies aim to prevent market makers from exploiting investors.

Regulation FD (“Fair Disclosure”) issued by the Securities & Exchange Commission establishes the basic requirement for avoiding “selective disclosure” and disseminating all communication of material corporate information to everyone at the same time. The basic rule of Regulation FD is that whenever the Company or someone acting on its behalf discloses any material nonpublic information to certain persons (e.g., stock brokers, investment analysts, shareholders, etc.), the Company must make public disclosure of that information simultaneously, if the disclosure is intentional, and promptly, if the disclosure is unintentional. The impetus behind Regulation FD is to avoid giving any person an unfair market advantage through selected access to confidential information.

Past data indicates a quarterly appearance in company data.  And the numbers do not indicate margins or indicate where the funds will be invested.

Should point a couple of things with this cash summary. The data hosting advanced fees were up $48 millions over the prior year. So substantially higher even without including Ellendales' 50 mw lease to Marathon-- Ellendale was restored to fully operation end of June. Company projects income from the 100 mw lease to the unnamed hyperscaler starting end of 2024 or in 2025. 2025 will see another Ellendale Buidling started and possibly a 3rd.On the Cloud Services side-- we know that clusters were more than doubled so far in 2024 but not all were generating income-- with plans for more to be acquired and leased out.There's a lot of unknowns here but enough clarity to see once again substantial revenue growth in the current year. And a discounted cash flow model on valuation would suggest use of a multiplier.

Cash items thus far this quarter for ApldMay 31- 148.1 millions in advance deposits on data center hosting-- income recognized as earnedJune 2 - up to 200 millions in loan commitments from private equityJuly- 25 millions from the Garden City earn outAugust 30 - 53.2 million dollar convertible issuesSept 5- 160 millions from Nvidia and "Related Companies" related is one the countries largest real estate developers.So total cash items for the quarter--586 milllions ( based on 200 million shares- about 2.93 cents per share) Keep in mind this does not include Cloud Service Revenues projected at 100-110 millions per year. Or included consulting and other revenues. Obviously no deductions for expenditures or noncash expenses.So assuming cloud services came in at 25 millions-- cash for the quarter-- nearly $4 per share. And keep in mind May 31 assets were nearly 756 millions. Float at 109 million shares -- being conservative with this cash per share figure based on adding 49 million new shares to total outstanding of 150 plus millions per Yahoo.So do you want to sell in the 2's or 3s.
